content: Safe Seizure: Brain seizure prediction using machine learning
title: Safe Seizure - Brain seizure prediction

content: Safe Seizure: Brain seizure prediction using machine learning Language: Python
title: Safe Seizure - Brain seizure prediction

content: 1 Problem Around 50 million people on Earth have chronic epilepsy. In about 40% of cases, patients have drug-resistant epilepsy against which anti-seizure treatments have no effect. Being able to predict, well in advance, when the next seizure will occur could significantly improve epileptic patients lives.
title: Safe Seizure - Brain seizure prediction

content: 2 Solution: Safe Seizure Using Machine Learning, the Safe Seizure team is able to predict if a seizure will occur up to 3 hours in advance using intracranial EEGs (iEEGs).
title: Safe Seizure - Brain seizure prediction

content: 3 Objectives Objective 1: Distinguish preictal (i.e. pre-seizure) from interictal (i.e. no-seizure) states ‚Äì> binary classification Objective 2: For preictal (i.e. pre-seizure) states, predict if a seizure will occur in 1, 2, or 3 hours ‚Äì> multi-class classification
title: Safe Seizure - Brain seizure prediction

content: 4 Results Results 1: overall accuracy of 84% Results 2: overall accuracy of 87% In Results 2, the mis-classifications that we absolutely want to avoid are circled in red. Also, in orange rectangles show a confusion between 2 and 3 hours prior to seizure.
title: Safe Seizure - Brain seizure prediction

content: 5 Algorithm The Machine Learning algorithm developed for the project is inspired by al-Qerem et al. 2020. Below is an outline of the sequential algorithm: The raw iEEG time series are denoised using Independent Component Analysis (ICA). The denoised signals are then filtered using a Discrete Wavelet Transform (DWT). Statistical indicators are extracted from the filtered signals (mean, std, entropy, mav‚Ä¶) Classification using a Random Forest Classifier (RFC)
title: Safe Seizure - Brain seizure prediction

content: Data analytics challenge from Kaggle
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: Olist challenge: healthily increase your e-commerce profits! Language: Python
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: 1 Problem How to increase Olist‚Äôs (Brazil‚Äôs largest department store) monthly profits while maintaining a healthy order rate?
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: 2 Solution This Data Analytics project makes use of the Brazilian E-Commerce Public Dataset to provide applicable solutions for increasing Olist‚Äôs monthly profits in a healthy and sustainable way.
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: 3 Objectives To address the problem, two objectives have been set: Identification of the main sources of loss (low-performing sellers) Simulation of two loss-reduction solutions
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: 4 Results
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: 4.1 Identify the worst-performing sellers The worst-performing sellers have been identified as the sellers with the highest monthly orders, usually with more than 80 orders per month.
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: 4.2 Loss-reduction solutions Solution 1: limiting strategy By limiting a seller‚Äôs number of monthly orders to 30 when their share of 1-star reviews are >10%, Olist‚Äôs monthly profits sustainably increase by 0.8%. Benefits: no sellers are banned ‚Äì> Olist doesn‚Äôt lose customers Reduce ‚Äúbad sellers‚Äù negative impact by 3.5 factor Trade-offs: Low impact on monthly profits: only 0.8% increase Solution 2: ban strategy By banning the worst-performing sellers from the online platform, Olist‚Äôs monthly profits increase by 17%. Benefits: High impact on monthly profits: 17% profit increase Trade-offs: Olist loses customers and monthly orders
title: Olist - Brazilian e-commerce challenge

content: Statistical modelling of Bayesian inference for in-situ biosignatures
title: Search for extraterrestrial life - Martian biosignatures

content: Search for extraterrestrial life - Martian biosignatures (a.k.a. biosignatures) Language: R
title: Search for extraterrestrial life - Martian biosignatures

content: 1 Background This project is the statistics chapter of my Master of Research thesis on traces of life on Mars. The search for life elsewhere is guided by the search for traces of ancient life in environments on Earth that are analoguous to Mars, like Antarctica for example. Such traces, called biosignatures, tend to be preserved in rocks sometimes several billion years old. There are many types of biosignatures, from organic molecules to micro-fossils. However, biosignatures are not equally reliable, detectable, and preserved in rocks. Also, there is no known biosignature that is a definite proof of life. Rather, identifying life, past or current, will most likely rely on a combination of various biosignatures. What is the optimal number of biosigantures needed to identify life? Is it better to detect more biosignatures that are easy to detect or fewer but more reliable?
title: Search for extraterrestrial life - Martian biosignatures

content: 2 Objectives Based on Catling et al. 2018 on exoplanet biosignatures, this project provides a Bayesian framework for in-situ biosignatures. A variance-based sensitivity analysis is then performed on the Bayesian model providing general guidelines for astrobiology strategies.
title: Search for extraterrestrial life - Martian biosignatures

content: 3 Results Bayesian model for in-situ biosignatures: ¬† ¬† the posterior term is the probability for a rock sample to be biogenic given the signatures detected within it and its environment geological environment; the likelihood term is the probability of a signature to be detected within the rock if it is biogenic and given the geological environment; the prior term is the initial belief that the rock is biogenic given its geological environment; the false positive term is the probability of a signature to be detected if the sample is NOT biogenic and given the geological context. ¬† Variance-based sensitivity analysis: The sensitivity analysis was performed using the Sobol' method from the R sensitivity package. The 1st order Sobol' indices were computed for the Bayesian model described above for up to 15 biosignatures (i.e. 15 iterations, n = 15). From the figure above, we can infer the following: When detecting a single biosignature, it is most important to have a deep understanding of the geological context; When detecting two biosignatures, it is equally important to have a deep understanding of (i) the geological context, (ii) the processes that produce the biosignatures, and (iii) the processes that produce similar but non-diagnostic of life; Detecting seven biosignatures or more does not help identifying life, and our understanding of the geological environment is negligible.
title: Search for extraterrestrial life - Martian biosignatures

content: 4 References Catling, D. C., Krissansen-Totton, J., Kiang, N. Y., Crisp, D., Robinson, T. D., DasSarma, S., ‚Ä¶ & Domagal-Goldman, S. (2018). Exoplanet biosignatures: a framework for their assessment. Astrobiology, 18(6), 709-738. Sobol, I. M., & Levitan, Y. L. (1999). On the use of variance reducing multipliers in Monte Carlo computations of a global sensitivity index. Computer Physics Communications, 117(1), 52-61.
title: Search for extraterrestrial life - Martian biosignatures
